condition.title: Problem
condition.p: The browser freezes with the loading widget spinning indefinitely when opening a document (or it takes too long to open).

cause.title: Cause
cause.p: There are a lot of reasons that can lead to a slow loading time (e.g. slow internet connection, bad customization that interferes with the document load process, large sized documents, etc).

steps-informal.p: In the most cases, the slow loading time is caused by a customization (a plugin or framework, or a custom option). In this case, it is recommended to try to reproduce the problem without any customizations.
In some cases, the problem can be solved by updating to the latest version to see if the problem is reproduced in the latest version.
Troubleshoot the requests made by the browser:

ol.li: Open a document that takes long to load in Web Author in Google Chrome.
Open the Developer Tools (e.g. by pressing F12).
Deselect the Disable cache" checkbox in the Network tab.
Clear the requests.
Reload the page.
Right-click on a request and select Save all as HAR with content.
Sort the requests by time (e.g. right-click, Sort, Time).
Look for the longest requests, inspect the URL, and try to find if they are made because of a customization (custom plugin or framework).
If nothing relevant is found, report the downloaded HAR to the Oxygen support team.

steps-informal.p: Troubleshoot the requests made by the server by enabling verbose HTTP(S) logs:

ol.li: Enable verbose HTTP logs by following the procedure from Enabling HTTP Request Logging for Debugging.
Reproduce the problem.
Open the server logs by following the procedure from How to Locate the Log File and the Log Configuration Fileâ€‹.
See the logs and try to find the ones that take a long time on the server.
If nothing relevant is found, report the found logs to the Oxygen support team.
Open the server logs by following the procedure from How to Locate the Log File and the Log Configuration File.
Look for "Long request" and "Took long time to compute" and see the URL of the requests that take a long time on the server.
If nothing relevant is found, report the found logs to the Oxygen support team.

steps-informal.p: Sometimes documents load slowly because of the time it takes to compute styles. This increases linearly with the size of the document and the size of the CSS rules. The CSS rules are mainly contributed by the framework. The styles are computed when loading both server-side and client-side.
To see how much time it takes the browser to render the page, follow these steps:

ol.li: Open the Developer Tools in Google Chrome (e.g. by pressing F12).
Go to the Performance tab.
Click on Record in the top-left corner.
Reload the page.
When the page fully loads, click Stop.
Click the Main section within the Performance tab.
In the bottom part, in the Summary tab, you should see a circle with the load time split between "Scripting", "Rendering", "Paint", "Idle", and "Other".
Check that "Rendering" time is reasonable.

steps-informal.p: Sometimes documents load slowly even if the main opened document is small, because it references many other documents that get expanded by either xi:include XML elements or DITA conref or conkeyref attributes.

For each referenced document that gets expanded, the application makes a request to an external server to retrieve the document content, thus the network speed and latency between the Web Author server and the server from where documents are retrieved is critical.

To troubleshoot this, enable network logs by following steps in Alternative Solution 3 and count how many requests are made when opening a document and how much time those requests took.
